bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
Short-Term Trend To determine the short-term trend, Malta consulted with the second edition of the Birds in Europe, in which the breeding population was estimated to be 1,000 -2,000 pairs. This data may imply an increase in the population size or an increase in research effort.
Long Term- Trend
The breeding of the Zitting Cisticola was first confirmed in 1973. Such species continued to spread itself every year and by 1980 it was common and widespread in both Malta and Gozo.

bird_report.population_trend_additional_info:
The Short-Term Trend
To determine the short-term trend, Malta consulted with the second edition of the Birds in Europe, in which the breeding population was estimated to be 5,025 - 8,025.
Long Term Trend
To determine the long-term trend, Malta consulted with the first edition of the Birds in Europe in which the breeding population was estimated to be between 3.000- 5,000 pairs.

bird_report.population_additional_info: Although the Mallard is being reported as a wintering species, the number of birds that winter in Malta is small (Sultana et al., 2011) and according to Fenech (2010) the species is "very irregular and very scarce." In view of this the population size was considered to fall under Class 1, however, such an estimate was based on expert opinion with no or minimal sampling.

bird_report.population_additional_info: In view that the common pigeon is a feral alien species it is not monitored per se. Although 90% of the 'wild' population of the feral Columba livia occurs in the Valletta harbour area it has spread to nearby locations such as Floriana, Blata l-Bajda, Marsa, Ħamrun, Gżira, Tas-Sliema as well as rural areas in Comino and parts of Gozo. Breeding usually occurs where these are allowed to breed as domesticated species in man-made semi-enclosed environments. Nonetheless, the species is also known to breed in various other environments, covering both urban and rural settings (including in house ventilators, holes, cervices and fissures within buildings, fortifications, bastions, city walls in urban settings, as well as in cliffs, screes, boulders, gorges, caves and other areas in rural environments). The nominate subspecies (subsp. livia) has not been reported to occur in Malta and the populations encountered in urban and rural settings are feral populations of the domestic taxon (subsp. domestica).

bird_report.range_trend_additional_info: Columba livia encompasses both the wild birds (Columba livia livia) which are however absent from Malta, and non-native feral birds (Columba livia domestica). This datasheet only covers the feral birds, which are alien species and not covered by the Birds Directive as they are not naturally occuring birds in the wild state in Malta.
